title: Symptomatic Hyperthyroidism Requiring Surgery
diagnosis_topic: Graves Disease Refractory to Medical Therapy
setup_script: “A 30-year-old woman with Graves disease presents with palpitations, weight loss, and ophthalmopathy despite high doses of methimazole and beta-blockers. She is considering definitive therapy and wants to discuss surgery versus radioactive iodine. How would you proceed?”

dynamic_flow.reply: “She reports palpitations, heat intolerance, tremors, and progressive weight loss despite medical therapy. She also has eye irritation and mild proptosis.”
“TSH is suppressed; free T4 and T3 are elevated. Thyroid receptor antibodies are positive.”
“She is not pregnant but has moderate ophthalmopathy. What options would you discuss with her?”
“How would her ophthalmopathy affect your recommendation?”
“What are the key indications for surgery in Graves disease?”
“This patient has failed medical therapy and has ophthalmopathy. Surgery is a reasonable choice. What preoperative steps are necessary?”
“She is continued on beta-blockers and methimazole. Potassium iodide is started 7 days prior to surgery.”
“Flexible laryngoscopy shows normal vocal cord function.”
“Describe the key technical steps of performing a total thyroidectomy in this patient.”
“The thyroid is markedly vascular and requires meticulous ligation of vessels and preservation of recurrent laryngeal nerves and parathyroid glands. What intraoperative risks should you anticipate?”
“Risks include recurrent laryngeal nerve injury, hypocalcemia, bleeding, and thyroid storm.”
“In the recovery unit, the patient develops perioral numbness and tingling. Serum calcium is 7.3 mg/dL. How would you manage this?”
“Her symptoms improve with IV calcium, and she is transitioned to oral calcium and vitamin D supplementation. Levothyroxine is started.”
“Final pathology confirms diffuse hyperplasia consistent with Graves disease; no malignancy is found.”
“She is referred to endocrinology for long-term levothyroxine management. How would you educate her about lifelong care?”

critical_decision_points: Recognition of hyperthyroidism refractory to medical management.
Counseling on definitive therapy options (surgery vs. radioactive iodine) and considering contraindications.
Ensuring preoperative euthyroidism to avoid thyroid storm.
Technical knowledge of thyroidectomy including preservation of nerves and parathyroid glands.
Immediate postoperative monitoring and management of hypocalcemia.
Long-term follow-up with endocrinology and patient education on hormone replacement.
